fracas-problems.comment: Gradable adjectives (e.g. big, small) usually assume some form of comparison class (i.e. "big for an N"). But some others do not e.g. four-legged, or the adjectival phrase ten foot long. Adjectives not requiring a comparison class permit straightforward predication without reference to a nominal property providing a comparison class: a ten foot long alligator is ten foot long.

fracas-problems.comment: Large and small (applied to the same comparison class) are opposites. If something is a small N it cannot be a large N, and vice versa. Some things can be neither large nor small Ns.

problem.why: Adjectives requiring a comparison class cannot usually be predicated in the absence of a common noun, unless some comparison class is clear from the wider context.

fracas-problems.comment: Some adjectives require an "intensional" comparison class: different inferences may follow when two distinct but co-extensive predicates provide the comparison class.

fracas-problems.comment: Note that both intensional and extensional comparison class adjectives support comparatives.

Comparison class adjectives can sometimes pick up a default comparison class from the subject NP. For example, knowing that Kim is a person provides a default scale for assessing cleverness in people. If Kim were known to be a dog, the assessment scale would be different.

problem.note: In Greek there is a distinction between phrasal and clausal comparatives.The phrasal comparative marker is the preposition "apo" , while the clausal one is the complex "apo oti" , which consists of "apo" and the invariant "oti" (from-wh).

fracas-problems.comment: Inferences (233)-(235) are similar to (230)-(232). Note however, that if "APCOM" can be interpreted as referring to a particular order (e.g. "the APCOM contract"), as it can in (233), the sentence ITEL won more orders than APCOM is ambiguous between a reading like that in (230)-(232), and one where ITEL won more than just the APCOM order ... see (236)

fracas-problems.comment: Inference patterns involving temporal reference are complicated by the interplay between tense, aspectual information, lexical semantics, defeasible interpretation principles such as narrative progression, rhetorical relations, a theory of action and causation, world knowledge, interaction between plurality, genericity and temporal/aspectual phenomena etc. Some of the inferences are very basic, some are more involved. The more complex examples give ample illustration of the fact that temporal phenomena are usually discourse phenomena.

p.script: Η ΙΤΕΛ έχει ενα εργοστάσιο στο Μπέρμινγκχαμ.
p.translit: I ITEL echei ena ergostasio sto Bermingcham.
p.morph: The[f,nom] ITEL has[pres,3.Sg] a[neut,acc] factory[neut,acc] in the[contr,neut,sg,acc] Birmingham.
p.english: ITEL has a factory in Birmingham.

fracas-problems.comment: (258) involves the lexical semantics of found.
Non-context dependent indexicals are reasonably straightforward:

p.script: Διήρκησε 2 μέρες.
p.translit: Lasted 2 days.

p.english: Today is Saturday, July 14th.

fracas-problems.comment: Ignoring counterfactual readings, 'before' and 'after' have the following transitivity properties: if X, Y and Z are either all state or accomplishment or achievement or activity denoting sentences we have X < Y. Y < Z. X < Z. where < \in {before; after}

problem.note: For the translation of "was present", I made a distinction in greek, between "was present=verb + adjective/ είμαι παρών" and "present= verb/ παρίσταμαι"

fracas-problems.comment: If X and Y are either all accomplishment or achievement denoting sentences with simple tenses 'before' and 'after' are inverses of each other:
X before Y iff Y after X.

fracas-problems.comment: Also "before", but not "after", can have a counterfactual meaning. Whether this is a distinct sense of "before" is open to debate:

p.script: Ο Σμίθ έφυγε απο τη συνεδρίαση πριν χάσει τη ψυχραιμία του.
p.translit: O Smith efyge apo ti synedriasi prin chasei ti psychraimia tou.
p.morph: The[m,nom] Smith left[past,3.Sg] from the[f,acc] meeting[acc] before lost[pres,3.Sg,subj] the[f,acc] temper[acc] his[m,gen].
p.english: Smith left the meeting before he lost his temper.

q.script: Έχασε ο Σμίθ τη ψυχραιμία του;
q.translit: Echase o Smith ti psychraimia tou?
q.morph: Lost[past,3.Sg] the[m,nom] Smith the[f,acc] temper[acc] his[m,gen]?.
q.english: Did Smith lose his temper?

h.script: Ο Σμίθ έχασε τη ψυχραιμία του.
h.translit: O Smith echase ti psychraimia tou.
h.morph: The[m,nom] Smith lost[past,3.Sg] the[f,acc] temper[acc] his[m,gen].

fracas-problems.comment: With "when" things are even more complicated. The problem is that it is often very difficult to tease apart the temporal from the causal dimension of "when", c.f.

p.script: Όταν άνοιξαν το M25, η κίνηση αυξήθηκε.
p.translit: Otan anoixan to M25, i kinisi afksithike.
p.morph: When opened[past,3.Pl] the[neut,acc] M25, the[f,nom] traffic[acc] increased[past,3.Sg,passive].
p.english: When they opened the M25, traffic increased.

fracas-problems.comment: "In" and "for" adverbials can be used as tests for the aspectual class of verb phrases (or sentences).

problem.note: In greek there's no equivalent form of past perfect continuous, so in the translation it was substituted with the greek form of past continuous, in order to show the duration of the action.

p.english: Since APCOM bought its present office building it has been paying mortgage interest on it for more than 10 years.

p.script: Όταν ο Τζόουνς πήρε τη δουλειά του στη CIA, ήξερε ότι δεν θα του επιτρεπόταν ποτέ να γράψει τα απομνημονεύματά του.

q.translit: Ischyei oti o Tzoouns den tha grapsei kai den tha tou epitrapei pote na grapsei ta apomnimonevmata tou?

p.script: Την περασμένη εβδομάδα ήξερα ήδη ότι όταν, σε διάστημα ενός μήνα, η Σμίθ θα ανακάλυπτε οτι εξαπατήθηκε, θα γινόταν έξαλλη.
p.translit: Tin persameni evdomada ixera idi oti otan, se diastima enos mina,i Smith tha anakalypte oti exapatithike, tha ginotan exalli.
p.morph: The[f,acc] last[f,acc] week[acc] knew[past,1.Sg] already that when, in time[acc] one[m,gen] month[gen], the[f,nom] would discover[cond,3.Sg] that duped[past,3.Sg,passive], would be[cond,3.Sg] furious[f,nom]
p.english: Last week I already knew that when, in a month's time, Smith would discover that she had been duped she would be furious.
